displaytitle: Understudy: The Moon Goddess and Rabbit-in-the-Moon

titles.title: Understudy: The Moon Goddess and Rabbit-in-the-Moon

makers.displaydate: 1959–2016; born New York, NY; died New York
makers.displaymaker: Anne Chu, 1959–2016; born New York, NY; died New York

texts.textentryhtml: Understudy is Chu’s response to an ancient Maya whistle in the form of the Moon Goddess Ix-Chel and the lunar rabbit, on long-term loan to the Princeton University Art Museum. In the Mayan context, the Moon Goddess, a symbol of fertility, gives birth to the lunar rabbit. Here, Chu’s rabbit-in-moon rests its mangled arm upon a ghosted figure intimating both fragility and instability. Creating a dialogue between ancient and modern, classic and avant-garde, Chu imbues her object with the aura of an artifact while also suggesting a reimagined contemporary world.
Anne Chu, New York, New York, gift; to Princeton University Art Museum, 2003.
